name: A Grand Miscellany : I Quiz | History | 20 Questions

questions.text: The public baths were an important part of Roman life. There were generally separate public baths for women in ancient Rome.
questions.explanation:
True.

	The women's baths were often in the same complex as the men's baths.

questions.text: Ancient Egyptians wore wigs in place of sun hats. What were they made of?
questions.explanation:
Slaves' hair.

	Rich people wore the wigs over their shaved heads.

questions.text: To show they ruled both parts of Egypt, what did Pharaohs wear?
questions.explanation:
Double crowns.

	A red crown for Upper Egypt, and a white crown for Lower Egypt.

questions.text: What did girls in medieval Spain put in their mouths to avoid unwanted kisses?
questions.explanation:
Toothpicks.

	In medieval Spain, it is thought that toothpicks bring bad luck.

questions.text: Built 2500 years ago, the huge Cloaca Maxima is still used in Rome. What is it?
questions.explanation:
A sewer.

	It was originally built to drain the marshy land on which the Forum stood.

questions.text: What were believed to encourage immoral behavior in the Renaissance?
questions.explanation:
Buttons.

	Women were forbidden to use them as fasteners on their dresses.

questions.text: When Priests held banquets in ancient Egypt, what unusual 'guest' did the guest list include?
questions.explanation:
Mummies.

	They were propped up at the table as a reminder that death was inescapable.

questions.text: Plato the Greek philosopher was also an Olypmpic athlete. What was his specialty?
questions.explanation:
Wrestling.

	This was one of the most popular sports in ancient Greece.

questions.text: One African tribe used to present each new Monarch with the same symbol of power. What was it?
questions.explanation:
Fly swatter.

	A fly swatter was a sign of power

questions.text: Alexander the Great conquered a huge empire in Africa, Asia and Europe. How old was he when he died?
questions.explanation:
33.

	He died 10 days after consuming too much food and drink at a banquet.

questions.text: What was India's famous Taj Mahal built for?
questions.explanation:
A tomb.

	It was built in the 1600s by the Mogul emperor Shah Jehan for his favorite wife, Mumtaz Mahal.

questions.text: What did Egyptians mummy-makers wash the insides of corpses with?
questions.explanation:
Wine.

	Egyptian mummies well over 3,000 years old have been found still very well preserved.

questions.text: If you were caught drinking this liquid in 16th-century Turkey, you could be executed. What was it?
questions.explanation:
Coffee.

	It was considered sacrilegious to drink a stimulant.

questions.text: The Church in Spain once called this drink 'Satan's beverage.' What was it?
questions.explanation:
Hot chocolate.

	Chocolate was brought to Spain from the New World, where it was drunk by the Aztecs.

questions.text: Who built the first light house?
questions.explanation:
Egyptians.

	A wood fire was kept burning in the tower of the Light house of Alexandria, one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World.

questions.text: Two years after she was murdered in 1355, what did Inez de Castro become?
questions.explanation:
A Queen.

	Her body was exhumed and she was crowned Queen of Portugal when her husband, Don Pedro, was crowned King.

questions.text: How old did the average Neanderthal live to be?
questions.explanation:
30.

	Disease and predatory animals meant an early death for these cave people.

questions.text: What did the ancient Egyptians prescribe beer as remedy for?
questions.explanation:
Hemorrhoids.

	They believed beer shrunk the hemorrhoids!

questions.text: Before napkins were invented, what did people wipe their mouth with at the table?
questions.explanation:
The tablecloth.

	Napkins were invented for just that purpose.

questions.text: Digging into early Etruscan tombs, what did archeologist find?
questions.explanation:
False teeth.

	They were discovered in tombs that were 2,500 years old.
